{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3459666,"name":"","username":"RayK","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/f17d59/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-12-15T22:35:52.265Z","cooked":"

I‚Äôm a mentor in the third year Team 9100, and this year we wanted to build a swerve robot. In order to have as much done in this new venture before the January 4 FRC kickoff, we opted for a Swerve Drive Specialties MK4n kit ordered through AndyMark, and REV Neo Vortex motors with integrated Spark Flex motor controllers because they were the only ones that were in stock. Our initial research suggested a slight preference for Kraken X60 motors, but these were backordered, and we didn‚Äôt want to risk fulfillment delays. The Spark Flex controllers each have an integrated encoder, and we bought a Through Bore Encoder for the steering shaft.

We assembled the four swerve modules without much trouble (SDS‚Äôs instructions were almost flawless) and used 1‚Äùx2‚Äù aluminum extrusions with pre-drilled holes to create a 29‚Äù square swerve robot. I will use the REV client App to test each module early this week but I don‚Äôt anticipate any problems (famous last words ).

Now the hard part. We‚Äôre a small team (2 mentors ‚Äì Al and myself) and I do the programming. I‚Äôm basically a C/C++ programmer ‚Äì not a great one but I get the job done. For this year I just want to get a basic joystick-controlled ‚Äúrobot-centric-view‚Äù operation working. ‚ÄúField-centric-view‚Äù will be for another year unless it‚Äôs not too difficult. We have a navX2-MXP that I used last year to keep our tank-drive robot moving straight in autonomous mode.

I looked around on the Internet and Chief Delphi for some example C++ code and found a few things that could be adapted, but before I plunge in to any of them, I wanted to get some advice from teams that have used REV motors/controllers in a C++ swerve drive robot. There was a code template for REV‚Äôs MaxSwerve, but it seems to be specifically for REV swerve kits and older motors/controllers; navX2-MXP has a C++ example for field-centric-drive, but it assumes Mecanum /drive and is 7 years old; there‚Äôs ‚ÄúYet Another Generic Swerve Library (YAGSL),‚Äù but it‚Äôs written in Java. Finally, there is the ‚ÄúSwerveBot‚Äù example code in WPILib, which seems promising. It would be nice to have some written documentation to help navigate through the code and customize it.

Any guidance and/or example code would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks, in advance,

Ray Kimber

Thanks for responding, Nathan and Skyehawk. I‚Äôm not familiar with the capabilities of YAGSL. Is it easy to get a robot up and running with Field Centric Drive using YAGSL? Is there ample documentation and/or tutorials to get somebody started? Is it widely used? If there‚Äôs nothing comparable in C++, I‚Äôd give Java some thought.

Thanks, guys.

For C++, the SparkMax Template is the only thing that comes to mind. You‚Äôd need to tweak a few lines to switch from SparkMax controllers to SparkFlex controllers, but it shouldn‚Äôt be too much work.

Skyehawk:

Yeah‚Ä¶ This is worth at least a temporary language change.

I second this. While C++ is a great language, I highly recommend switching to Java for FRC because:

  1. It‚Äôs easier for students to learn.
  2. Your students can earn an AP Computer Science A score for free .
  3. Since the vast majority of teams use Java, you‚Äôll get more support and access to a wider range of codebases.

If you‚Äôre open to switching to Java, YAGSL is your best bet.

RayK:

Is it easy to get a robot up and running with Field Centric Drive using YAGSL?

Yes, and without having to write a single line of code.

RayK:

Is there ample documentation and/or tutorials to get somebody started?

YAGSL is the most well-documented swerve drive library out there, which is a big part of its success. There‚Äôs a complete guide on setting it up, fine-tuning the gains, and some really helpful troubleshooting tips.

RayK:

Is it widely used?

Yes, by more than a hundred teams.

I can also say the NSTRIKE does a phenomenal job of supporting teams with YAGSL, so if you go that route you are in good hands.

LPryor:

There‚Äôs so much inertia with java in FRC, there are tons of libraries and modules you‚Äôd likely have to port over. I don‚Äôt think the juice is worth the squeeze. (And I come from a C++/C# background)

I‚Äôm with @LPryor here - coming from some previous teams that were C++, it was swimming upstream the whole way. The communal knowledge in FRC is too strong in the Java area to not take advantage of that. That‚Äôs coming from an old C UNIX kernel guy - sometimes you just gotta get on the train and my current teams are all Java.

YAGSL is your most likely ticket to success - no need to re-invent the wheel (I was part of a swerve drive effort more than 1/2 a decade ago in C++ and it was a lot of work to get right - not that complicated once you get the math in your head but not trivial because we were mostly alone it seemed).

Swerve is a solved problem now and there is some great stuff out there so leverage your resources and grab it IMO.

Which drive gearing did you run? IMO L2+ is not great with vortex as their low end torque did not seem to allow it to accelerate quickly and that also led to it having an insanely fast top end. L2 is probably a solid starting place for speed and acceleration.

I did not know those youtube tutorials existed! Thats so awesome!

Anyways, YAGSL is updated to the 2025 season as it starts in a few short weeks and there have been alot of great changes from everyone! My personal favorite change to YAGSL is the addition of SwerveInputStream which makes controlling swerve drives a breeze for most teams! We also integrated the amazing maple-sim into YAGSL for physics simulation which adds a necessary layer of realism to sim.

I would highly encourage you to try out the beta if you‚Äôre not working with a real robot. If you are working with a real robot take a good look at the changes to REVLib just so you are the shellshocked come kickoff.

Good luck this year!
